title: 113_hr3202
content: The Act is titled the "Essential Transportation Worker Identification Credential Assessment Act" and includes a comprehensive security assessment of the Transportation Security Card Program. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide a comprehensive assessment of the transportation security card program's effectiveness in enhancing security for regulated facilities and vessels within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security must conduct a comprehensive assessment of the transportation security card program's effectiveness in enhancing security for regulated facilities and vessels. This assessment will be carried out by a national laboratory or a maritime security university-based center within the Department of Homeland Security network. It will evaluate the program's ability to address security risks in the maritime environment and identify any deficiencies. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct an assessment of the transportation security card program's effectiveness in addressing security risks in the maritime environment. A corrective action plan will be submitted to relevant committees within 60 days of the assessment. The Secretary of Homeland Security will submit a corrective action plan to relevant committees within 60 days of assessing the transportation security card program's effectiveness. The plan will include an implementation plan with benchmarks, potential reforms, regulatory revisions, or legislative proposals, and will be considered in any Department rule-making related to the program. The Comptroller General will review the plan within 120 days of its issuance. The Comptroller General will review the corrective action plan within 120 days of its issuance, assessing the implementation of recommendations from national laboratories, maritime security centers, and previous Comptroller General recommendations. The review findings will be reported to the Committee on Homeland Security and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. The Comptroller General will review the corrective action plan within 120 days, assessing recommendations from national laboratories and maritime security centers. The findings will be reported to relevant congressional committees. The Secretary of Homeland Security is restricted from issuing a final rule on transportation security card readers until the Comptroller General informs the committees on Homeland Security and Transportation and Infrastructure. The Comptroller General will inform relevant congressional committees that the submission is in line with recommendations. The Secretary will update the list of compatible transportation security card readers. The Comptroller General will oversee the implementation of transportation security card reader requirements, excluding certain final rules. This oversight will occur regularly for a period of three years following the issuance of the corrective action plan. The Comptroller General will report every six months for three years to relevant committees on the implementation of transportation security card reader requirements. SEC. 3. NO ADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED. No extra funds are allowed for this Act and its amendments. Existing funds will be used for implementation.
